title: 111_hr2931
content: The "Kyle Barthel Veterans and Service Members Mental Health Screening Act" mandates confidential screenings for suicide and substance abuse prevention. The "Kyle Barthel Veterans and Service Members Mental Health Screening Act" requires mandatory mental health screenings for active duty service members to reduce suicide prevalence, ensuring confidentiality and in-person screenings by licensed professionals. The "Kyle Barthel Veterans and Service Members Mental Health Screening Act" mandates mental health screenings for active duty service members to identify suicide and substance abuse risk factors. Screenings must be conducted in person by a health professional following set standards developed by the Secretary of Defense. Screenings should occur within 30 days of induction, as part of required physical exams, and before deployment for contingency operations. The "Kyle Barthel Veterans and Service Members Mental Health Screening Act" requires mental health screenings for active duty service members to identify suicide and substance abuse risk factors. Screenings must be conducted in person by a health professional following set standards developed by the Secretary of Defense. The Secretary of Defense shall not use screening results to prohibit a member from returning to the United States or being discharged from the armed forces. The Secretary of Defense shall conduct a study to collect data on licensed mental health providers employed, their workload, retirement dates, geographic locations, and member access to screening and treatment services. The Secretary of Defense will evaluate the redistribution of mental health providers and hiring additional staff to improve mental health screening and treatment for members. A report on the study results must be submitted to Congress within one year. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will collect data on mental health providers and member access to services. The study aims to collect data on licensed mental health providers employed by the Secretary, their expected workload, retirement dates, geographic locations, and veterans' access to services. It also evaluates redistributing providers geographically, assigning different tasks, and hiring additional staff. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is conducting a study to determine the cost and benefits of hiring licensed mental health providers to improve mental health treatment for veterans. A report on the study's results will be submitted to Congress within one year. The Secretary of Defense mandates TBI screenings for active duty members by licensed professionals during physical exams and deployment periods. The Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish a joint protocol to share reports on screenings for transitioning members and veterans.
